entry.title: Combined summary - Concrete MATT opcodes
entry.summary: The email exchange discusses various topics related to Bitcoin programming and proposals. Antoine expresses concerns about the risks of cross-input inspection in off-chain contracts, suggesting the implementation of smart bitcoin contracting primitives to mitigate these risks. He also mentions the need for more advanced bitcoin contracts through the introduction of a matrix or set of "tags" to encode subsets of introspected inputs/outputs.Salvatore thanks Johan for his comments and implementation, mentioning that the reordering of parameters was done for aesthetic purposes. He explains that the deferred output amount check is not enough for coinpools but has no cost if there is already a parameter. Salvatore emphasizes the advantages of the optional feature of CCV and mentions that efforts to define and add explicit introspection can proceed independently without nullifying these advantages.Johan appreciates the update on taptree verification and mentions implementing the updated opcodes in btcd. He suggests reordering the opcode parameters and proposes either removing the amount preservation check or proposing a more powerful amount introspection machinery. Johan seeks Salvatore's thoughts on these suggestions.The email also mentions a proposal for the core opcodes of MATT by Salvatore Ingala. The code is implemented in the bitcoin-inquisition repository fork and includes OP_CHECKCONTRACTVERIFY. The changes compared to the previous draft include replacing OP_CHECK{IN, OUT}CONTRACTVERIFY with a single opcode, introducing an additional `flags` parameter, modifying the order of parameters, and defining special values and flags. The author notes that while some special values may not be useful in applications, they were included for flexibility. With the new opcode, the full generality of MATT can be achieved with just two opcodes: OP_CHECKCONTRACTVERIFY and OP_CAT. Additional opcodes and introspection may benefit certain applications, and the author looks forward to comments and starting a BIP proposal.Overall, the email exchange covers discussions on mitigating risks in off-chain contracts, introducing advanced bitcoin contracts, and proposing improvements to the core opcodes of MATT. The authors provide insights into their thoughts and implementations and express openness to feedback and further development.
